title: ‘His Grandmother Asked About One Woman She Said She Had Liked.’
description: Discussing a “horrible” rock band, dreaming of a secret life and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Plácido Domingo Says He Has the Coronavirus
description: “I beg everyone to be extremely careful,” the opera singer said in a Facebook post on Sunday after developing a fever and cough and testing positive for the virus.
content: The opera star Plácido Domingo disclosed on Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Jessica Testa
title: Christian Siriano and Dov Charney Are Making Masks and Medical Supplies Now
description: Fashion designers and manufacturers are rebooting their operations to help with shortages of masks and gowns in the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Last week the American fashion industry went dark as stores and factories closed, both voluntarily and by government decree, to help prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kuttner
title: This Stimulus Bill Will Not Save the Economy From Collapse
description: Let’s not repeat the slow and timid response to the financial crash of 1929.
content: When the stock market crashed in 1929, the Dow plummeted from its September peak of 381.17 to a low of 41.22 in July 1932. Because so few Americans owned stocks, it took three years for the financial collapse to cycle though the rest of the economy. Unemployment only gradually increased, to a peak of about 25 percent in early 1933. Gross domestic product fell steadily, ultimately declining by about 30 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Martin
title: Where Is God in a Pandemic?
description: The honest answer is: We don’t know. But even non-Christians may find understanding in the life of Jesus.
content: Last summer I underwent radiation treatment. And every time I passed through the doorway marked “Radiation Oncology,” my heart seemed to skip a beat. While I was in little danger (my tumor was benign, and, yes, one sometimes needs radiation for that), I daily met people who were close to death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek
title: Emergency Economic Rescue Plan in Limbo as Democrats Block Action
description: Democrats voted against moving forward on a plan expected to cost $1.8 trillion or more, seeking stronger protections for workers and stricter rules for bailed-out businesses.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Sunday blocked action on an emerging deal to prop up an economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, paralyzing the progress of a nearly $2 trillion government rescue package they said failed to adequately protect workers or impose strict enough restrictions on bailed-out businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Reid J. Epstein
title: ‘Wartime President’? Trump Rewrites History in an Election Year
description: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
content: WASHINGTON — With the economy faltering and the political landscape unsettled as the coronavirus death toll climbs, a stark and unavoidable question now confronts President Trump and his advisers: Can he save his campaign for re-election when so much is suddenly going so wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
description: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
content: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Weddings, Funerals and Life in Dire Times
description: Readers offer their stories of coping: the county jail as a wedding venue, a father mourning from the safety of a car, remote piano lessons and more.
content: On Saturday we ran a sampling of letters we received when we asked readers how they were dealing with the disruption in their lives. Below are several more responses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
title: Coronavirus Drives the U.S. and China Deeper Into Global Power Struggle
description: Many experts warn that an international health and economic crisis calls for more cooperation, not confrontation, between Washington and Beijing.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the podium at the White House briefing room one afternoon last week, his prepared remarks included a reference to the “corona virus.” But a close-up photograph revealed that Mr. Trump had used one of his signature Sharpies to cross out the word “corona,” changing the phrase to “Chinese virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
description: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
content: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Weddings, Funerals and Life in Dire Times
description: Readers offer their stories of coping: the county jail as a wedding venue, a father mourning from the safety of a car, remote piano lessons and more.
content: On Saturday we ran a sampling of letters we received when we asked readers how they were dealing with the disruption in their lives. Below are several more responses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 22, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 22, 2020.
content: An article on Page 4 about the lack of diversity in Atlanta’s theater scene misspells the surname of the artistic director of the Out of Hand theater company. It is Ariel Fristoe, not Fristo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Throwing Billions at the Coronavirus
description: Will the government's plan to save the economy work?
content: Greetings, fellow stir-crazed humans. While you work your way through your frozen food supply, we’re here to help you parse what’s next in business, tech and the economy, which continues to be devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. Keep calm and wash your hands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: The Mixed-Up Brothers of Bogotá
description: How two sets of twins, scrambled at birth, had their lives changed in an instant.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Maybe this is the moment to experiment with fermentation: Get a sourdough starter going, for bread down the line, or consider making kombucha.
content: Good morning. There was fog on the harbor near my home the other morning, the cobblestones wet on the street before it, the sidewalks empty in four directions. The air smelled of spring on a working waterfront: salt and seaweed, fuel and tar. It was Walt Whitman stuff, though the poet didn’t write about scent when he crossed the river, and I felt a little joy amid the tremulous, untouchable nervousness of the current moment. I went inside and fed the sourdough starter. I observed the miracle of the kombucha (above). Life’s all around us. We need to celebrate it, every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Lorenzo Sanz, Who Led Comeback of Real Madrid, Dies at 76
description: He helped the soccer club win its first European Cup in 32 years. He  is also the most prominent Spaniard to die of the coronavirus.
content: Lorenzo Sanz, the former president of Real Madrid who helped return the Spanish soccer club to victory in Europe’s top competition after more than three decades, died on Saturday in Madrid. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cornelia Dean
title: Daniel S. Greenberg, Science Journalist and Iconoclast, Dies at 88
description: He challenged peers who acted as “cheerleaders” for science, and influenced government science policy with a Washington-based newsletter.
content: Daniel S. Greenberg, a writer and editor who broke ground in science journalism by reporting on the research enterprise not with reverence but with journalistic rigor, died on March 9 at his home in Washington. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Getting Pregnant Was a Challenge, Then the Coronavirus Happened
description: Women across the country are learning that their fertility procedures need to be postponed for an indefinite period of time.
content: After nearly two years of trying to have a baby, Karen Rzonca, 32, was hoping that this would be the month she finally got pregnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: A Podcast Playlist to Help Distract You (for the Most Part)
description: A crowdsourced selection of podcast episodes for this time, from the people who love them and make them.
content: As you shelter in place or take other measures to help stop the spread of the coronavirus, you may find yourself with silence to fill. And though podcasts are famously calibrated for a commuter’s journey, there are plenty out there to help pass the time and calm you at home, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel M. Horn
title: How America Can Avoid Italy’s Ventilator Crisis
description: I’m one of the doctors on the front lines of the war against this virus. You can help me fight.
content: Without swift action, parts of the United States will run out of ventilators in the coming weeks. Early signals from New York and Seattle are alarming: both cities are already reporting intensive care unit bed shortages and looming ventilator shortages, weeks before the estimated peak of the projected coronavirus caseload.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: African Animal That Charges
description: Ed Sessa reminds us that we are one.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Are you still with me? We’re going to get through this, you and I.Here are five things I’m doing to stay sane, and please feel free to join in:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The U.S. Shut Down Its Economy. Here’s What Needs to Happen in Order to Restart.
description: Whole sectors of the United States economy have gone dark to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Here’s what comes next.
content: WASHINGTON — The American economy has stopped working.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Has Roughly 5% of Coronavirus Cases Worldwide
description: The increase in cases stems from both the rapid growth of the outbreak and significantly increased testing in the state.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo disclosed new statistics on Sunday that indicated that New York State now has roughly 5 percent of coronavirus cases worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Young Voters Know What They Want. But They Don’t See Anyone Offering It.
description: For the first time, millennials and Generation Z have enough electoral clout to seriously compete with their elders. But many feel more disillusioned than empowered.
content: The oldest of them were just out of college on 9/11; the youngest were not yet born. Over the two decades that followed, they all came of age under storm clouds: of war, of recession, of mass shootings, wildfires and now a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Matthew Futterman
title: Canada Withdraws From Summer Olympics as I.O.C. Weighs Postponement
description: Faced with growing frustration from athletes and some national committees, the International Olympic Committee said it would decide within four weeks on the Tokyo Games.
content: The International Olympic Committee, faced with mounting pressure to postpone the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, said on Sunday that it would decide within four weeks whether to delay or scale down the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Eli Miller, One of the Last of the Seltzer Men, Dies at 86
description: He began delivering sparkling water in 1960, when hundreds of seltzer men plied the streets. He continued until 2017, when there were almost none.
content: Long before sparkling water with brand names like Polar, Perrier and La Croix crowded bodega refrigerators and apartment dwellers used household carbonators to bottle bubbling beverages themselves, New Yorkers relied on seltzer men to deliver refreshment in clanking glass bottles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Aronson
title: ‘Covid-19 Kills Only Old People.’ Only?
description: Why are we OK with old people dying?
content: “Not just old people: Younger adults are also getting the coronavirus,” a news network declared on its website last week. The words seemed to suggest that Covid-19 didn’t matter much if it was a scourge only among the old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: A Boom Time for the Bean Industry
description: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
content: Tim McGreevy has worked in the bean business for more than 30 years. But when he scanned the bean aisles at a grocery store in Pullman, Wash., on Sunday, he saw something he had never seen before: empty shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
title: For Children Fleeing War, a Tent Becomes a School
description: In northwestern Syria, children forced from their homes cannot remember a normal life. Volunteer teachers are trying to give them one.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The camp school is only a tent — cold and cramped, its floor covered by a rug whose intricate pattern is hard to make out under the crowd of kneeling students. The walls are plastic sheets. There are no desks, no chairs, no toilet, hardly any books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Young Voters Know What They Want. But They Don’t See Anyone Offering It.
description: For the first time, millennials and Generation Z have enough electoral clout to seriously compete with their elders. But many feel more disillusioned than empowered.
content: The oldest of them were just out of college on 9/11; the youngest were not yet born. Over the two decades that followed, they all came of age under storm clouds: of war, of recession, of mass shootings, wildfires and now a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Matthew Futterman
title: Canada Withdraws From Summer Olympics as I.O.C. Weighs Postponement
description: Faced with growing frustration from athletes and some national committees, the International Olympic Committee said it would decide within four weeks on the Tokyo Games.
content: The International Olympic Committee, faced with mounting pressure to postpone the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, said on Sunday that it would decide within four weeks whether to delay or scale down the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: What to Do if You or a Loved One Might Have the Coronavirus
description: A vast majority of those infected with the coronavirus will develop only mild to moderate symptoms. But many people remain frightened and wonder how and when to seek medical care.
content: As the coronavirus spreads around the globe, the reality is that most of us will probably get it at some point. Fortunately, a vast majority of people will develop only mild to moderate symptoms that will not require hospitalization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Region Is Now an Epicenter of Global Pandemic
description: New York City and its suburbs account for roughly 5 percent of global cases, forcing officials to take urgent steps to stem the outbreak.
content: Three weeks after its first coronavirus infection was discovered, the New York City region reached an alarming milestone on Sunday: It now accounts for roughly 5 percent of the world’s confirmed cases, making it an epicenter of the global pandemic and increasing pressure on officials to take more drastic measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Target Apologizes for Selling N95 Masks in Seattle
description: The company said the masks were offered for sale “in error” at some stores in Washington State, which has been a hot spot for the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The retailer Target apologized on Saturday after coming under criticism for selling N95 masks, which are in acute demand by medical providers during the coronavirus pandemic, at some stores in Washington State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Prison Riots in Colombia Over Virus Fears Leave at Least 23 Dead
description: The deaths followed countrywide prison protests in which inmates said authorities were not doing enough to control coronavirus.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — At least 23 inmates died in clashes with prison authorities over the weekend after what prisoners described as protests against officials for not doing enough to control the spread of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Stock Futures Sink as Washington Struggles Over Rescue Plan
description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Ernesto Londoño
title: Warmer Weather May Slow, but Not Halt Coronavirus
description: Nature may help diminish the pandemic if aggressive measures to control the spread of infections continue, experts say. That doesn’t mean the virus won’t return.
content: Communities living in warmer places appear to have a comparative advantage to slow the transmission of coronavirus infections, according to an early analysis by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brittany Harris, Naseem Beauchman
description: The couple were Facebook friends for more than a decade, but didn’t met in person until 2017, when they matched on the League dating app.
content: Brittany Virginia Lucille Harris and Dr. Naseem Neon Beauchman were married March 21 at the home of Ms. Harris’s parents in Oakland, Calif. Leon F. Beauchman, the father of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Meritage Resort and Spa in Napa, Calif., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more people should be postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Trump Writes to Kim Jong-un Offering Help in Virus Fight, North Korea Says
description: The North, which says it is waging an all-out campaign against the coronavirus, expressed “sincere gratitude” for the president’s letter.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — President Trump has sent a letter to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, expressing his willingness to help the North battle the coronavirus, North Korea said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Tariro Mzezewa and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: They Went Abroad to Study. Now They Are Stranded.
description: As borders closed and airlines canceled flights, the biggest lesson for many Americans studying abroad was this: You’re on your own.
content: Channing Stirrat traveled to Ecuador to study biology. Nicholas Nerli flew to Morocco to further his Arabic studies. For Adina Rombro, a study-abroad program offered a chance to dive into Peruvian culture and history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Kreider
title: I Just Called to Say … the Phone Call Is Back
description: The warm timbre of a human voice in your ear is more real, more present, than text on a screen. We need that now.
content: The other night my friend Margot called. It’s not unusual for me to hear from Margot — we’ve been friends for more than 30 years, email frequently, have dinner every month or two, and I stay over at her house whenever I’m in town. But Margot never calls. Practically no one does; my few surviving telephonic friendships antedate the internet. But Margot has a cold, and because her husband is immunocompromised, she’d had to quarantine herself in their guest room; she was, in effect, the invalid mother confined to her room upstairs in some Victorian novel. She’d been just about to email me when she thought, why would I email? and picked up the phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cristian Fracassi and Alessandro Romaioli
title: We Made Copies of Ventilator Parts to Help Hospitals Fight Coronavirus
description: Even in a quarantine, innovation can help.
content: BRESCIA, Italy — Our small city has been on lockdown for nearly two weeks. The streets are silent. Many factories are closed. The only people allowed outside are those walking their dogs, heading to the grocery store or those who have permission from the government. A few of our friends are hospitalized from the coronavirus, with many more in quarantine at home. Hundreds of people have died here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pilon
title: Trump Didn’t Know People Could Die From the Flu. His Grandfather Did.
description: What Frederick Trump’s death, in 1918, tells us about the costs of mismanaging a pandemic.
content: In May 1918, a German immigrant businessman, husband and father of three in Queens took his last breaths. At the time, no one really knew why he was dying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José Andrés
title: José Andrés: We Have a Food Crisis Unfolding Out of Sight
description: America has fed millions through disasters before. Mobilize restaurant workers now.
content: Writing in the middle of two devastating cholera pandemics in the early 1800s, the great French culinary thinker Brillat-Savarin articulated a truth we urgently need to grasp today: “The destiny of nations depends on how they feed themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
title: Traffic and Pollution Plummet as U.S. Cities Shut Down for Coronavirus
description: A satellite that detects pollution linked to cars and trucks shows declines over major metropolitan areas, including Los Angeles, Seattle, and New York.
content: A satellite that detects pollution linked to cars and trucks shows declines over major metropolitan areas, including Los Angeles, Seattle, and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘This is Not Life as Usual’: Cuomo Calls on New Yorkers to Abide Isolation
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that cases of the coronavirus in the state had reached 15,168, and called on New Yorkers to stop ignoring social distancing.
content: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that cases of the coronavirus in the state had reached 15,168, and called on New Yorkers to stop ignoring social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery
title: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring
description: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
content: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Fed Could Bolster Groups of Businesses and Localities With Funds in G.O.P. Bill
description: Republican senators want to create $425 billion in funding to back Fed emergency lending.
content: Senate Republicans have proposed giving the Federal Reserve access to $425 billion in funding that it could use to extend emergency support to flailing businesses or struggling localities — an approach that would keep central bankers at the center of the coronavirus economic response in ways that could prove politically fraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pilon
title: Trump Didn’t Know People Could Die From the Flu. His Grandfather Did.
description: What Frederick Trump’s death, in 1918, tells us about the costs of mismanaging a pandemic.
content: In May 1918, a German immigrant businessman, husband and father of three in Queens took his last breaths. At the time, no one really knew why he was dying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José Andrés
title: José Andrés: We Have a Food Crisis Unfolding Out of Sight
description: America has fed millions through disasters before. Mobilize restaurant workers now.
content: Writing in the middle of two devastating cholera pandemics in the early 1800s, the great French culinary thinker Brillat-Savarin articulated a truth we urgently need to grasp today: “The destiny of nations depends on how they feed themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery
title: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring
description: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
content: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Fed Could Bolster Groups of Businesses and Localities With Funds in G.O.P. Bill
description: Republican senators want to create $425 billion in funding to back Fed emergency lending.
content: Senate Republicans have proposed giving the Federal Reserve access to $425 billion in funding that it could use to extend emergency support to flailing businesses or struggling localities — an approach that would keep central bankers at the center of the coronavirus economic response in ways that could prove politically fraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Ana Swanson and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Bets Business Will Answer Call to Fight Virus, but Strategy Bewilders Firms
description: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to invoke the Defense Production Act to commandeer resources for the federal government is based on a bet that he can cajole the nation’s biggest manufacturers and tech firms to come together in a market-driven, if chaotic, consortium that will deliver critical equipment — from masks to ventilators — in time to abate a national crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: She Was More Than a Statistic in a Pandemic: ‘We Didn’t Want Her to Get Lost’
description: Loretta Mendoza Dionisio, outgoing and unstoppable, died of the coronavirus, a statistic in a growing U.S. count. But her life meant much more.
content: Her name was Loretta, but they called her Lettie. She stood 4 feet 10 inches tall. She was outrageously friendly, the kind of person liable to invite the sales clerk at T-Mobile to join the family for dinner. This made her children cringe but was also something they loved. Pure Lettie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Deniers and Disbelievers: ‘If I Get Corona, I Get Corona.’
description: Many have ignored the urgent calls for social distancing. How much they are worsening the coronavirus outbreak may never be known.
content: NOVATO, Calif. — A climbing destination on the remote eastern side of the snow-capped Sierra Nevada, Bishop, Calif., was packed last weekend, as crowded as any holiday, despite growing calls for isolation in advance of a predicted wave of coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Catie Edmondson
title: Rand Paul Tests Positive for Covid-19, Fueling Anxiety in the Capitol
description: The Kentucky Republican is the first senator to be diagnosed with the novel coronavirus. He went about his routine for days after being tested, potentially exposing many colleagues.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans were struggling to salvage a more than $1 trillion economic rescue package to respond to the coronavirus crisis when they got the message on Sunday afternoon: One of their own had been walking around the Capitol with Covid-19 for days as they debated how best to confront the rapidly spreading pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Justine Roach, Hrishikesh Desai
description: The couple met in June 2017 through the dating app Bumble.
content: Justine Victoria Roach and Hrishikesh Padmanabh Desai were married March 21 at the home of Ms. Roach’s parents in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Laura Geller officiated at a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Hindu wedding traditions. The couple had planned to wed at the Ojai Valley Inn, a resort in Ojai, Calif., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more people should be postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Bridging 2 Continents Puts Strain on Canada’s ‘Astronaut Families’
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 22, 2020.
content: “The husbands who live overseas in China are like migrating penguins who go to search for food for their families.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alex Fishman, Anthony Shirk
description: The couple met in September 2014 through the dating app Hinge.
content: Alex Ethan Fishman and Anthony Richard Shirk were married March 21 at their home in New York. Rabbi Gary Katz officiated. On Nov. 8, the couple is to have a celebratory ceremony led by Rabbi Matthew L. Green at the Roundhouse, an events space in Beacon, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ and ‘Pet Sematary’
description: The 10th season of Larry David’s comedy wraps up, while a Stephen King adaptation comes to Amazon and Hulu.
content: CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM 10 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Throughout the 10th season of this semi-autobiographical comedy series, Larry David — playing a fictionalized version of himself — has been preparing to open a coffee shop next door to another establishment just to tick off its owner. In this season finale, he welcomes patrons into his “spite store,” gets a second opinion on his knee injury and instigates a dispute between expectant parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charu Suri
title: Fee Waivers, Virtual Art Shows and Online Cooking Lessons
description: Some in the travel industry are stepping up with offers for everything from online yoga classes to storage space for displaced students.
content: With flights canceled around the world, and bars and restaurants shutting down as efforts to control coronavirus cases accelerate, some hotels, cultural institutions and car rental companies are extending a helping hand with efforts that range from community outreach to fee waivers. Others, including museums, are coming up with virtual offerings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sandra Stevenson
title: Coronavirus, Recession, Skijoring: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 23, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: With Live Sports Gone, Announcer Offers Play by Play of the Everyday
description: Nick Heath narrates his videos of people doing mundane things, like crossing the street, with the verve and dramatic flair of competitive sports.
content: The narration begins customarily, with the play-by-play announcer enthusiastically welcoming his audience live to a competition unfolding on the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: A Mustang Crisis Looms in the West
description: With too many animals on public lands and too many on the public’s hands, the federal wild horse management program is short of money and palatable solutions.
content: CHALLIS, Idaho — Dawn broke over the peaks of the Lost River Range, revealing a chase in the wide open valley below. Seven wild horses crashed through the sage, dark manes billowing in the golden light, pursued by a government contractor in a glossy helicopter that dodged left and right like a mechanical Border collie, driving the band forward into a hidden corral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: She Had to Choose: Her Epileptic Patient or Her 7-Year-Old Daughter
description: The fragile, low-paying existence of home health aides at the epicenter of the pandemic.
content: When New York City closed its public schools, Cindy Urena, a home health aide for Sunnyside Community Services in Queens, faced a choice: stop seeing a client with severe epilepsy or leave her 7-year-old daughter alone at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Some Tips on How to Stay Sane in a World That Isn’t
description: The coronavirus outbreak has magnified all kinds of fears. Try living in the moment. Take stock of what’s working. Turn off the television.
content: Erasing anxiety from daily life isn’t an option for most people today. But therapists, clergy and meditation specialists say there are simple and accessible ways to overcome debilitating panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman and Natalie Keyssar
title: Geese May Not Inspire You, but They Certainly Take Your Mind off the Virus
description: Watching birds that do not practice social distancing is a nice break from washing your hands and disinfecting friends.
content: Watch birds. Geese if you’ve got them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan, Vanessa Swales and Neil Vigdor
title: Police Tread Lightly as Pandemic Spreads
description: Facing sweeping new safety orders, a frightened public and health risks of close contact, many police departments have decided that, for now, less is more.
content: If you have a fender bender in Nashville these days, chances are you’ll be filing your report by phone. In Philadelphia, the police are trying not to take drug dealers to jail. In Hilton Head, S.C., the authorities have seemed particularly focused on one offense: gathering and drinking on the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: In Seattle, It Started With Panic. Then the Deeper Anxiety Set In.
description: In a state that has seen more deaths from the coronavirus than any other, the stress has started to multiply. Jobs lost. Kids underfoot. Parents at risk. “It’s exhausting,” one woman said.
content: SEATTLE — Shannon Koyano is a 39-year-old single mother living, nervously, in the place where the coronavirus got its first and deadliest foothold in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: The Virus Can Be Stopped, but Only With Harsh Steps, Experts Say
description: Scientists who have fought pandemics describe difficult measures needed to defend the United States against a fast-moving pathogen.
content: Terrifying though the coronavirus may be, it can be turned back. China, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan have demonstrated that, with furious efforts, the contagion can be brought to heel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As State Pleas Mount, Trump Outlines Some Federal Action; Senate Democrats Block Stimulus Package
description: New York State has 15,000 cases, roughly 5 percent of the pandemic’s growing global total. Senator Rand Paul tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: In a Pandemic, Religion Can Be a Balm and a Risk
description: As scientists and politicians struggle for a response to the coronavirus, many people are turning to faith. But some practices raise public health concerns.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Down on earth, the coronavirus outbreak was felling lives, livelihoods and normalcy. A nation-spanning blessing seemed called for. So up went a priest in a small airplane, rumbling overhead at an epidemiologically safe distance from the troubles below, wielding a sacred golden vessel from a cockpit-turned-pulpit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Citing Threat to Israeli Democracy, Netanyahu Opponents Take Battle to Supreme Court
description: Critics accuse Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of a “coup d’état” under the cover of the coronavirus. He says he is saving lives.
content: Citing a threat to Israeli democracy, opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked the Supreme Court on Sunday to block what they described as a power grab by the caretaker government under the guise of combating the coronavirus epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Bans Groups of More Than 2 to Stop Coronavirus as Merkel Self-Isolates
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel went into isolation after learning that her doctor had tested positive.
content: BERLIN — Germany on Sunday barred groups of more than two people from gathering, except for families, and Chancellor Angela Merkel later said she herself was going into isolation because her doctor had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Wu, Weiyi Cai, Derek Watkins and James Glanz
title: How the Virus Got Out
description: We analyzed the movements of hundreds of millions of people to show why the most extensive travel restrictions to stop an outbreak in human history haven’t been enough.
content: We analyzed the movements of hundreds of millions of people to show why the most extensive travel restrictions to stop an outbreak in human history haven’t been enough.
source.name: The New York Times
